Description: Mould-made scarab in Egyptian blue; details on the back unknown; underside incised with representation of two animals arranged one above the other, likely a lion attacking a prey which turns its head towards the lion; perhaps sun disc behind lion's back; in dark blue paste; surface quite eroded.
Curator's comments: The number JE39125 was given to four different scarabs in Egyptian blue. From the photographs provided by the Egyptian Museum in Cairo (two views of undersides and one of a back), it is not sure which one corresponds to this scarab. In any case, they seem to be genuine products of the 'Scarab Factory' (on its various productions see Gorton 1996, 91-131; Webb forthcoming). Lion attacking a prey is a recurrent theme on Egyptian blue scarabs and scaraboids produced at the “Scarab Factory”. This scarab belongs to a type which was widely distributed in the Mediterranean area, particularly in Eastern Greece, and Southern Russia (Gorton 1996, 121-127, type XXXIV, subtype B). This group varies in style with other animal representations on Naukratite scarabs and scaraboids - animals with more elongated bodies, finer incisions - giving the impression that they are of better workmanship (Gorton 1996, 122). Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.) forthcoming. Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum, 16th –17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OE.62) (phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Egyptian Museum, Cairo
